title: A Pattern Language
author: Christopher Alexander
summary: You can use this book to design a house for yourself with your family; you can use it to work with your neighbors to improve your town and neighborhood; you can use it to design an office, or a workshop, or a public building. And you can use it to guide you in the actual process of construction.

title: An Elegant Puzzle
author: Will Larson
summary: A human-centric guide to solving complex problems in engineering management, from sizing teams to handling technical debt. There’s a saying that people don’t leave companies, they leave managers. Management is a key part of any organization, yet the discipline is often self-taught and unstructured.

title: Analysing Architecture
author: Simon Unwin
summary: Analysing Architecture offers a unique 'notebook' of architectural strategies to present an accessible introduction to the elements of architecture. It explores the underlying themes that shape architectural design.

title: Antifragile
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
summary: Antifragile is a standalone book in Nassim Nicholas Taleb’s landmark Incerto series, an investigation of opacity, luck, uncertainty, probability, human error, risk, and decision-making in a world we don’t understand. Taleb defines 'antifragile' as things that gain from disorder.

title: Art of War
author: Sun Tzu
summary: The Art of War is an ancient Chinese military treatise dating from the Late Spring and Autumn Period. The work, which is attributed to the ancient Chinese military strategist Sun Tzu, is composed of 13 chapters. Each one is devoted to an aspect of warfare and how it applies to military strategy and tactics.

title: Basic Economics
author: Thomas Sowell
summary: Basic Economics is a citizen's guide to economics, written for those who want to understand how the economy works but have no interest in jargon or equations. In his distinctive and accessible style, Sowell explains the general principles underlying different economic systems.

title: Build
author: Tony Fadell
summary: Tony Fadell led the teams that created the iPod, iPhone and Nest Learning Thermostat and learned enough in 30+ years in Silicon Valley about leadership, design, startups, Apple, Google, decision-making, mentorship, devastating failure and unbelievable success to fill an encyclopedia. So that's what this book is.

title: Creativity, Inc.
author: Ed Catmull
summary: From Ed Catmull, co-founder (with Steve Jobs and John Lasseter) of Pixar Animation Studios, comes an incisive book about creativity in business and leadership—sure to appeal to readers of Daniel Pink, Tom Peters, and Chip and Dan Heath. Creativity, Inc. is a manual for anyone who strives for originality and the first-ever, all-access trip into the nerve center of Pixar Animation.

title: Design and Analysis of Experiments
author: Douglas C. Montgomery
summary: This bestselling professional reference has helped over 100,000 engineers and scientists with the success of their experiments. The new edition includes more software examples taken from the three most dominant programs in the field: Minitab, JMP, and SAS.

title: Diplomacy
author: Henry Kissinger
summary: A seminal work on foreign policy and the art of diplomacy. Moving from a sweeping overview of history to blow-by-blow accounts of his negotiations with world leaders, Henry Kissinger describes how the art of diplomacy has created the world in which we live, and how America’s approach to foreign affairs has always differed vastly from that of other nations.

title: Extreme Ownership
author: Jocko Willink, Leif Babin
summary: Two U.S. Navy SEAL officers who led the most highly decorated special operations unit of the Iraq War demonstrate how to apply powerful leadership principles from the battlefield to business and life.

title: Finite and Infinite Games
author: James Carse
summary: There are at least two kinds of games. One could be called finite, the other infinite. A finite game is played for the purpose of winning, an infinite game for the purpose of continuing the play.

title: First Things First
author: Stephen Covey
summary: I'm doing more and more in less and less time, but I feel like I'm doing the things that matter less and less. Does this sound like you? First Things First can help you understand why so often our first things aren't first.

title: Getting Things Done
author: David Allen
summary: Based on the premise that in a knowledge worker world, the total number of tasks is not clear, Getting Things Done (GTD) provides a comprehensive system for organizing and tracking tasks and projects.

title: Guns, Germs, and Steel
author: Jared Diamond
summary: A transnational history of humanity over the last 13,000 years. Diamond argues that gaps in power and technology between human societies originate primarily in environmental differences, which are amplified by various positive feedback loops.

title: Hackers and Painters
author: Paul Graham
summary: The book is a collection of essays that Graham has written over the years. The topics range from the history of programming languages to the design of web applications, but they all share a common theme: how to think like a hacker.

title: High Growth Handbook
author: Elad Gil
summary: Well-known technology executive and angel investor Elad Gil has worked with high-growth tech companies like Airbnb, Twitter, Google, Stripe, and Square as they've grown from small companies into global enterprises. This book is the playbook for turning a startup into a unicorn.

title: High Output Management
author: Andrew S. Grove
summary: The essential skill of creating and maintaining new businesses—the art of the entrepreneur—can be summed up in a single word: managing. In High Output Management, Andrew S. Grove, former chairman and CEO (and employee number three) of Intel, shares his perspective on how to build and run a company.

title: How to Read a Book
author: Mortimer J. Adler
summary: A guide to reading for understanding. It provides a set of rules for reading, ensuring that you get the most out of every book you read. It distinguishes between four levels of reading: Elementary, Inspectional, Analytical, and Syntopical.

title: How to Take Smart Notes
author: Sönke Ahrens
summary: The key to good writing and thinking is not the writing process itself, but the note-taking process that happens before. This book explains the Zettelkasten method, which allows you to build a external brain to store and retrieve ideas.

title: Influence
author: Robert Cialdini
summary: The classic book on persuasion, explaining the psychology of why people say 'yes'—and how to apply these understandings. Dr. Robert Cialdini is the seminal expert in the rapidly expanding field of influence and persuasion.

title: Invent and Wander
author: Jeff Bezos
summary: In this collection of Jeff Bezos's writings—his unique and strikingly original annual shareholder letters, plus numerous speeches and interviews that provide insight into his background, his work, and the evolution of his ideas—you'll gain an insider's view of the why and how of his success.

title: The Lessons of History
author: Will Durant, Ariel Durant
summary: A concise survey of the history and nature of human progress. The Durants distill their knowledge of 5,000 years of history into a set of profound observations on the human condition.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
summary: A series of personal writings by Marcus Aurelius, Roman Emperor from 161 to 180 AD, recording his private notes to himself and ideas on Stoic philosophy.

title: Poor Charlie's Almanack
author: Charles Munger
summary: The wit and wisdom of Charlie Munger: Warren Buffett's partner at Berkshire Hathaway. This book compiles Munger's talks, lectures, and public commentary, offering a unique insight into his multidisciplinary approach to life and investing.

title: The Power of Habit
author: Charles Duhigg
summary: In The Power of Habit, Pulitzer Prize–winning business reporter Charles Duhigg takes us to the thrilling edge of scientific discoveries that explain why habits exist and how they can be changed.

title: Principles
author: Ray Dalio
summary: Ray Dalio, one of the world’s most successful investors and entrepreneurs, shares the unconventional principles that he’s developed, refined, and used over the past forty years to create unique results in both life and business.

title: Principles for Dealing with the Changing World Order
author: Ray Dalio
summary: From the legendary investor Ray Dalio, author of the #1 New York Times bestseller Principles, who has spent half a century studying global economies and markets, comes a bold, new framework for understanding the changing world order.

title: Propaganda and the Public Mind
author: Noam Chomsky, David Barsamian
summary: In this interview collection, Noam Chomsky offers insights into the institutions that shape the public mind in the service of power and profit. He discusses the media, intellectual elites, and the mechanics of manufacturing consent.

title: Seeking Wisdom
author: Peter Bevelin
summary: A spirit of multidisciplinary learning. This book is a compilation of the mental models and wisdom from Charlie Munger, Warren Buffett, and other great thinkers, focusing on how to avoid stupidity and make better decisions.

title: Six Easy Pieces
author: Richard Feynman
summary: The essentials of physics explained by its most brilliant teacher. Six Easy Pieces captures the essence of physics in a simple, straightforward style.

title: Skin in the Game
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
summary: Skin in the Game is about having a tangible stake in the outcome of your actions. It argues that the world is safer and more just when decision-makers suffer the consequences of their mistakes.

title: Striking Thoughts
author: Bruce Lee
summary: A collection of Bruce Lee's wisdom on life, philosophy, and martial arts. The book is organized into 72 topics and covers everything from existence and art to self-actualization.

title: The 22 Immutable Laws of Marketing
author: Al Ries, Jack Trout
summary: Two world-renowned marketing consultants reveal the definitive rules that govern the game of marketing. Violate them at your own risk.

title: The Art of Doing Science and Engineering
author: Richard Hamming
summary: Highly effective thinking is an art that engineers and scientists can be taught to develop. By presenting actual experiences and analyzing them as they are described, the author conveys the developmental thought processes employed and shows a style of thinking that leads to successful results.

title: The Book of Five Rings
author: Miyamoto Musashi
summary: A text on kenjutsu and the martial arts in general, written by the Japanese swordsman Miyamoto Musashi around 1645. It is considered a classic treatise on military strategy.

title: The Boron Letters
author: Gary C. Halbert
summary: A series of letters written by history's greatest copywriter Gary C. Halbert, explaining the secrets to effective marketing. The letters were written to his youngest son Bond while Gary was in prison.

title: The Craft of Research
author: Wayne C. Booth et al.
summary: This book explains how to choose a topic, how to develop a problem and a solution, how to find and use evidence, and how to write a clear and compelling argument.

title: The Delusions of Crowds
author: William Bernstein
summary: Bernstein explores the history of mass manias, from the Crusades to modern financial bubbles, illustrating how human beings are susceptible to contagions of unreason.

title: The Design of Everyday Things
author: Don Norman
summary: A powerful case for good design. Norman explores why some products satisfy while others only frustrate, and he shows how good design is not just about aesthetics, but about usability and understanding the user.

title: The Edward Bernays Reader
author: Edward Bernays
summary: A collection of writings by Edward Bernays, the 'father of public relations'. It covers his theories on propaganda, engineering consent, and the manipulation of public opinion.

title: The Four Steps to the Epiphany
author: Steve Blank
summary: The classic book that launched the Lean Startup revolution. It offers a step-by-step guide for startups to find their customers and build a successful business.

title: The Richest Man in Babylon
author: George S. Clason
summary: Beloved by millions, this timeless classic holds the key to all you desire and everything you wish to accomplish. This is the book that reveals the secret to personal wealth.

title: The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People
author: Stephen R. Covey
summary: Covey presents a holistic, integrated, principle-centered approach for solving personal and professional problems. With penetrating insights and pointed anecdotes, he reveals a step-by-step pathway for living with fairness, integrity, service, and human dignity.

title: The Story of Philosophy
author: Will Durant
summary: A brilliant and concise guide to the lives and ideas of the great philosophers, from Plato to John Dewey.

title: The Timeless Way of Building
author: Christopher Alexander
summary: This book provides the foundation for the Pattern Language. It presents a new theory of architecture, building, and planning which has at its core that age-old process by which the people of a society have always pulled the order of their world from their own being.

title: The Wealth of Nations
author: Adam Smith
summary: The Wealth of Nations is the magnum opus of the Scottish economist and moral philosopher Adam Smith. It is a foundational text in classical economics.

title: Theory of Games and Economic Behavior
author: John von Neumann, Oskar Morgenstern
summary: This is the classic work upon which modern-day game theory is based. It contains the complete mathematical theory of the zero-sum two-person game.

title: Things Hidden Since the Foundation of the World
author: René Girard
summary: An astonishing work of cultural criticism, this book is widely recognized as a brilliant and devastating challenge to conventional views of literature, anthropology, religion, and psychoanalysis.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
summary: The major work of Nobel Prize winner Daniel Kahneman. He explains the two systems that drive the way we think: System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System 2 is slower, more deliberative, and more logical.

title: Thinking in Systems
author: Donella H. Meadows
summary: Thinking in Systems is a concise and crucial book offering insight for problem solving on scales ranging from the personal to the global. It brings systems thinking out of the realm of computers and equations and into the tangible world.

title: What You Do Is Who You Are
author: Ben Horowitz
summary: Ben Horowitz, a leading venture capitalist, modern management expert, and New York Times bestselling author, combines lessons both from history and from modern organizational practice with practical and often surprising advice to help executives build cultures that can weather both good and bad times.

title: Working in Public
author: Nadia Eghbal
summary: Nadia Eghbal takes an inside look at modern open source software development and its evolution over the last two decades—and its ramifications for an internet reorienting itself around individual creators.

title: World Order
author: Henry Kissinger
summary: Henry Kissinger offers a deep meditation on the roots of international harmony and global disorder. Drawing on his experience as one of the foremost statesmen of the modern era, advising presidents, traveling the world, observing and shaping the central foreign policy events of recent decades, Kissinger now reveals his analysis of the ultimate challenge for the twenty-first century.
